Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). Further evaluation revealed no evidence of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), Atrio-Ventricular Block (AVB) or complete heart block. The patient has a history of a birth-related injury resulting in a Lefort-type facial fracture.  During the hospitalization, the patient experienced episodes of atrial flutter (AFL) treated with electrical cardioversion. A permanent pacemaker (PPM) was implanted due to the presence of junctional rhythms and bradyarrhythmias, and an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) was suggested for further arrhythmia management.  The patient also presents with bilateral ventricular pacing (BiV) to address the heart's conduction abnormalities. Discharge planning includes follow-up appointments with the patient's cardiologist and electro-physiologist for continued management of the LBBB and device programming optimization.

Patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of completed junctional rhythm, atrial flutter, and brady arrhythmia. The patient also has a history of birth defect related to the heart and underwent LeFort surgery in the past. The patient is currently fitted with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) and implanted cardiac defibrillator (ICD) due to the presence of bundle branch block (BBB), namely Other left bundle branch block (LBBB).  The patient's most recent ECG indicates that the LBBB is present, and there is also evidence of right bundle branch block (RBBB). Due to the concomitant occurrence of the two BBBs, the patient is at risk of developing heart block or atrioventricular block (AVB).  The patient's availed cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) to mitigate the possible onset of AV block. To date, the PPM has been effective in regulating the patient's heart rhythm, and the ICD is in place to manage any unexpected heart events that may arise.  During the patient's hospitalization, the team has taken note of the patient's brady arrhythmia and conducted further testing. The results show that the brady arrhythmia was due to the BBB, and it has not worsened despite the presence of the LBBB.  Based on the patient's current condition, it is recommended that the patient continue to follow up with their cardiologist regularly. There is also a need to remain vigilant for any potential complications that may arise from the LBBB and RBBB. The patient may require biventricular pacing or alternative CRT in the future as deemed appropriate by the treating physician.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient had a history of brady arrhythmia since birth, requiring a permanent pacemaker placement (PPM) at a young age. The patient also had a completed junctional rhythm and a history of atrial flutter (aflutter), for which a bi-ventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (BiV ICD) was placed.  During the hospitalization, the patient was monitored for any arrhythmias or further cardiac events. A routine electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed the presence of a left bundle branch block (LBBB), indicating a delay in the electrical conduction system of the heart. Although right bundle branch block (RBBB) was not evident, the possibility cannot be excluded.  The patient was also evaluated for the presence of any atrioventricular block (AVB) or other cardiac conduction abnormalities. While the patient did have a history of completed junctional rhythm, there were no current signs of AVB or any other significant cardiac conduction abnormalities.  Overall, the patient's hospitalization was uneventful, and the patient was stable at the time of discharge. The patient was advised to follow up with their cardiologist to monitor for any changes or progression of the LBBB or any other underlying cardiac pathology.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted to the hospital due to a recent diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). Upon admission, it was discovered that the patient also had a history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and an AV block. The patient underwent a completed junctional catheter ablation procedure to address these issues.  The patient has a history of abnormal heart rhythms that were managed with an Anti-tachycardia Pacing Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD/ICD) device. The patient also had a Lefort procedure in the past to address structural abnormalities in the jaw.  During this admission, the patient experienced periods of bradycardia that were treated with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) placement. The patient was also diagnosed with Atrial Flutter and underwent a biventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (BiV-ICD) implantation to manage his heart condition.  The patient has been discharged and advised to follow up with his primary care physician and cardiologist as per their recommendations. The patient was given recommendations to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow-up visits to manage any potential recurrence of his heart conditions.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). During the hospital stay, diagnostic testing confirmed the presence of bundle block as well as some other conduction abnormalities, including a history of completed junctional rhythm and atrioventricular block (AVB).   The patient's medical history included a Lefort surgery in their earlier years, and the presence of a pacemaker (PPM) as well as an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) due to a history of atrial flutter (aflutter) and bradycardia. Both devices were functioning properly throughout the hospital stay.  The patient was treated with close cardiac monitoring and was deemed to not need any further interventions to address the bundle block. The overall stability and function of the bundle branch block was monitored through the hospitalization.  In summary, the patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other LBBB, and their testing confirmed the presence of a bundle block as well as some other conduction abnormalities. There was evidence of prior completed junctional events and the patient had a history of aflutter and bradycardia, requiring a PPM and ICD. Throughout the hospitalization, the patient had close cardiac monitoring and was found to be stable. No further interventions were needed.

Patient Summary: The patient was diagnosed with other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and completed junctional atrioventricular block (AVB). They had a history of a Lefort fracture at birth and had a permanent pacemaker (PPM) implanted for bradycardia. The patient also had a biventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) due to atrial flutter.  Hospital Course: The patient initially presented to the hospital with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. Upon evaluation, they were found to be in atrial flutter with a rapid ventricular response. However, due to the patient's underlying LBBB, they were unable to undergo standard treatment with rate control medications. The patient underwent cardioversion, which was successful in returning them to sinus rhythm.  Further evaluation revealed that the patient had a completed junctional AVB, and it was determined that their atrial flutter was likely due to the presence of this block. The patient was referred to the electrophysiology service for consideration of further management with an ablation procedure.  Given the patient's history of prior bradycardia and permanent PPM, close monitoring was required. The patient remained stable and was eventually discharged with plans for follow-up with their primary care provider and electrophysiologist.

Patient Name: Johnny Smith Date of Admission: July 1, 2021 Date of Discharge: July 5, 2021  Diagnosis: Other left bundle branch block (LBBB)  Medical History: The patient had a history of completed junctional rhythm and atrial flutter with conduction over an accessory pathway. Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for an elective implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) placement due to his LBBB pattern. During the procedure, the medical team noted that the patient also had right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrioventricular block (AVB). The ICD was successfully implanted, and the patient recovered well.  Recommendations: The patient was advised to monitor the wound and report any signs of infection or bleeding. The patient was also instructed to follow up regularly with his cardiologist and to avoid strenuous activities until cleared by the medical team.  Follow-up: The patient will continue to receive regular follow-up care with his cardiologist. The ICD will monitor the patient's heart rhythm to detect any arrhythmias or abnormalities. The medical team will adjust the ICD as needed to ensure optimal function.  Conclusion: In summary, Johnny Smith was admitted with Other LBBB and underwent successful ICD placement. He was discharged with recommendations for follow-up care and monitoring.

Patient Name: [Name]  Medical Record Number: [MRN]  Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block  Hospital Course:   The patient was admitted to the hospital due to dizziness and palpitations. The initial workup showed Other Left Bundle Branch Block. The patient's past medical history was significant for completed junctional rhythm, aortic valve replacement, atrial flutter, and bradycardia. The patient had also undergone a LeFort I and II midface advancement surgery.  During the hospital stay, the patient received a permanent pacemaker (PPM) placement due to symptomatic bradycardia. Additionally, an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) was implanted for secondary prevention of ventricular arrhythmias due to the underlying cardiac disease.  The patient remained in the hospital for observation and was discharged with close follow-up with the outpatient cardiology team.  In summary, the patient was diagnosed with Other Left Bundle Branch Block, and underwent PPM and AICD implantation for symptomatic bradycardia and secondary prevention of ventricular arrhythmias.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). Medical history revealed a birth defect that resulted in the patient requiring a permanent pacemaker (PPM) insertion. An atrioventricular block (AVB) resulting in bradycardia was diagnosed and treated with the PPM. The patient had a history of atrial flutter (AFlutter) that was treated with an atrial implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD).  During the hospitalization, the patient was found to have completed junctional rhythm and a right bundle branch block (RBBB) on ECG. Further diagnostic testing confirmed LBBB. To optimize cardiac function, the patient underwent a biventricular pacemaker (BiV) implantation.  LeFort procedure, a surgical technique used to treat maxillary facial fractures, was ruled out due to cardiac considerations. The patient was discharged with recommendations for ongoing management of her cardiac conditions.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient previously had a completed junctional rhythm and was found to have a biventricular ICD inserted due to a history of recurrent atrial flutter (aflutter). This was complicated by the presence of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) installed for a congenital heart disease recognized since birth, and subsequently replaced with an AVB (atrioventricular block) mode pacemaker. The patient was later found to have a RBBB (right bundle branch block) along with the pre-existing LBBB.   The patient was managed with beta-blockers and referred for further management by an electrophysiologist. A LeFort procedure was also planned to address the congenital heart abnormality. The patient remained brady and required constant monitoring for arrhythmias. Due to the complexity of the patient's previous medical history, the patient had an additional atrial intracardiac defibrillator (AICD) implanted to ensure adequate cardiac function. Close follow-up was recommended for this patient, as they continue to have a high risk for arrhythmias related to bundle branch block.

Patient X was admitted to the hospital due to a diagnosed case of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The medical team noted the presence of a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrioventricular block (AVB) on the greeting ECG. Following further evaluation, it was discovered that the patient had completed junctional rhythm and necessitated the insertion of an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) to aid in their treatment.  The patient's medical history was notable for a LeFort procedure as well as placement of a permanent pacemaker (PPM). Additionally, there were reported instances of atrial fibrillation (Aflutter) and biventricular pacing (BiV) during previous hospitalizations.  Throughout the patient's stay in the hospital, measures were taken to address potential issues stemming from the LBBB diagnosis, including monitoring for instances of bradycardia. The care team ensured that the patient was stable upon discharge, and provided comprehensive instructions for follow-up care.  In summary, Patient X presented with Other LBBB, accompanied by RBBB, AVB, and completed junctional rhythm. Treatment included the placement of an AICD, with previous interventions including a LeFort procedure and PPM placement. Atrial fibrillation and biventricular pacing were also previously noted. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for ongoing care.

Patient was a 55-year-old male who presented with chief complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath. The patient had a history of Other left bundle branch block since birth, and an implanted automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) for the same. The AICD was functioning normally, and no interventions were required during hospitalization.  During hospitalization, the patient underwent an electrocardiogram, which showed completed junctional escape rhythm along with evidence of Atrial flutter (aflutter). The patient's symptoms were attributed to brady-tachy syndrome, which was managed with the use of AICD settings and medications. The patient was also found to have right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrioventricular block (AVB), which did not require any interventions at the time of hospitalization.  The patient was also evaluated for any structural abnormalities, and a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest and pelvis showed no significant findings. The patient had a history of Lefort fracture and had a permanent pacemaker (PPM) implanted as a result. The PPM was functioning normally during the hospitalization period.  The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block, RBBB, and atrioventricular block. The patient was advised to continue the use of the AICD and medications as prescribed, and to follow-up with the treating physician as scheduled. The patient was also advised to make lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and exercise, to manage his symptoms and maintain overall health.  Overall, the patient's hospitalization was uneventful, and he was stable at the time of discharge. The patient was given instructions on how to manage his symptoms and was advised to seek medical attention in case of any complications.

Patient X was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The patient had a history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and underwent atrioventricular block (AVB) completed junctional rhythm while in hospital. The patient had an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) in place due to their history of bradycardia and underwent a pacemaker generator exchange (PPM) during the current hospital stay.   During the hospitalization, the patient developed atrial flutter (aflutter) and underwent biventricular (BiV) pacing to manage their condition. The patient was also evaluated by the cardiology team and underwent a LeFort procedure due to their risk of cardiovascular events.   At discharge, the patient was stable and was educated on how to manage their AICD and PPM. The patient was advised to continue their medications and follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider to monitor their heart health.

Patient presented with a history of Other Left Bundle Branch Block. The patient had previously undergone a procedure for Bundle Branch Block and Right Bundle Branch Block. The surgery was completed to correct the blocks but unfortunately the patient continued to exhibit Left Bundle Branch Block. The patient had a history of complete atrioventricular block and had undergone placement of an atrial synchronous pacing system with a junctional escape rhythm. The patient had also previously undergone placement of an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) due to a history of atrial flutter. The patient received a permanent pacemaker (PPM) with rate-responsive pacing in 2016. The patient was found to have atrial flutter with 2:1 conduction and underwent biventricular device implantation in 2018. The patient had a history of brady and underwent a Lefort procedure. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue monitoring for any symptoms or changes in their condition.

Patient:   The patient was diagnosed with Other left bundle branch block, and subsequently underwent a series of medical interventions to manage their condition. Upon examination, it was determined that the patient had a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and an atrioventricular block (AVB) completed junctional, which necessitated the use of various medical devices and treatments.   Management:  As part of their treatment, the patient received an artificial cardiac pacemaker (AICD) to regulate their heart rate and rhythm. Additionally, an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was also installed to protect them against episodes of atrial flutter (aflutter) and ventricular arrhythmias (VAs).   The patient also received a permanent pacemaker (PPM) to correct their bradycardia, which was caused by their birth defect of incomplete bundle branch block. Along with this, biventricular pacemaker (BiV) placement was also considered by the medical team owing to the presence of the LBBB combined with the AVB.   Finally, the patient underwent a LeFort procedure to repair their facial fractures incurred in a recent accident. Due to the patient's underlying cardiac condition, they received continuous cardiac monitoring throughout their recovery period.  Discharge:  Following the successful completion of their treatment regimen, the patient was discharged with follow-up appointments scheduled for regular monitoring of their cardiovascular health. They were advised to monitor their symptoms and to seek immediate medical attention in the event of any unusual or concerning discomfort. The patient was also instructed to avoid certain activities, such as driving or operating heavy machinery, if they experience any dizziness or episodes of syncope.  It is recommended that they continue taking prescribed medications, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and keeping up-to-date with routine check-ups with their healthcare provider.

Patient A was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). Initial evaluation demonstrated a Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) with an accompanying Atrioventricular Block (AVB). After further testing, it was discovered that the patient had a Completed Junctional Rhythm.  Due to the severity of the patient's condition and the potential for further heart complications, it was recommended that an Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) be implanted. An Atrial Insertable Cardiac Device (AICD) was also implanted due to the patient's history of Atrial Flutter.  The patient underwent a surgical procedure to correct the blockage in their Left Bundle Branch. Though successful, the procedure resulted in temporary Bradyarrhythmia.  During the patient's hospital stay, an EKG revealed the presence of a biventricular pacing pacemaker (PPM). The patient was discharged with instruction to follow-up closely with their healthcare provider to monitor their LBBB and overall cardiac health.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The medical team conducted various tests, including an electrocardiogram which revealed evidence of a completed junctional rhythm without any sign of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB). An atrioventricular block (AVB) was also noted during the tests.  The patient had a history of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) implantation due to congenital heart block (CHB) since birth. A LeFort procedure was previously performed to correct the craniofacial abnormalities resulting from the patient's birth defect.  The patient was observed to experience several episodes of atrial flutter (AFL) with rapid ventricular response and subsequently underwent a biventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (BiV ICD) implantation. The device was programmed to monitor the heart's activity and provide necessary therapies if required.  The patient was treated with medications to control bradycardia and was closely monitored until stable enough to be discharged from the hospital. The medical team also administered intravenous antibiotics to prevent infection postoperatively.  The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and continue to follow up with the treating physician for regular check-ups and device monitoring. The patient was also provided with appropriate counselling on the management of the underlying condition and the proper care of the device.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient has a history of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and complete atrioventricular block (AVB). The patient was treated with completed junctional and AICD/ICD therapy. AICD was implanted due to brady arrhythmia since birth. The patient also had a previous history of congenital heart disease and underwent a Lefort procedure. The patient had a pacemaker (PPM) to manage the LBBB, but recently developed atrial flutter (aflutter) and required upgrade to a biventricular device (BiV).  During the hospital stay, the patient's BiV pacing settings were optimized, and the patient was started on appropriate anticoagulation therapy for the atrial flutter. The patient responded well to therapy, and the BiV was able to manage the LBBB and improve cardiac function. The patient was discharged with appropriate outpatient follow-up arrangements made.

Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Date of Admission: 8/10/2021 Date of Discharge: 8/15/2021  Diagnosis: Other left bundle branch block, completed junctional rhythm, atrial flutter, and brady-tachy syndrome  Treatment: - The patient was admitted with symptoms including dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath. After a thorough examination, it was determined that the patient had a left bundle branch block (LBBB) with a completed junctional rhythm, atrial flutter, and brady-tachy syndrome. - The patient had a permanent pacemaker (PPM) installed in the past due to a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrioventricular block (AVB) and with a history of sick sinus syndrome. A cardiac resynchronization therapy defibrillator, also known as a biventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), was implanted to improve LBBB and heart failure based on the clinical manifestation. - The patient was prescribed appropriate medication to adjust his heart rate and rhythm, including anti-arrhythmic drugs and anticoagulants. - A LeFort procedure was performed to address the patient's nasal deformity and corresponding breathing issues.  Outcome: - The patient's cardiac function has improved, and his symptoms have decreased. - The patient was followed up by a cardiologist and an ear, nose, and throat specialist after discharge. - He was instructed to take the prescribed medications regularly and maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle. - The patient was advised to continue regular monitoring and check-ups to maintain the function of ICD and PPM.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient's medical history revealed a birth defect affecting the heart, which was treated with a completed junctional ablation and implantation of an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD).   During the hospitalization, the patient experienced periods of bradycardia and atrial flutter, which were successfully treated with medication and electrical cardioversion. The AICD was programmed to switch between pacing and defibrillation modes, and it effectively prevented any episodes of ventricular tachyarrhythmias.  Electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram showed evidence of a bifascicular block with right bundle branch block (RBBB) and left anterior fascicle block, as well as a first-degree AV block. However, there were no signs of progressive heart failure or cardiomyopathy.  The patient underwent a successful Lefort-1 osteotomy for maxillomandibular advancement (MMA) to treat obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The surgical procedure was performed under general anesthesia, without any complications.  It was determined that the patient required a permanent pacemaker (PPM) due to persistent atrioventricular (AV) block and symptomatic bradycardia. The implantation of the PPM was completed without any complications, and the patient remained stable throughout the procedure.  The patient was discharged with prescriptions for antiplatelet and anticoagulation therapy, loop diuretics, and heart failure medication. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the electrophysiologist and the surgeon to monitor the patient's cardiovascular and respiratory health.  In summary, the patient was diagnosed with Other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and underwent treatment including implantation of an AICD, medication, and a Lefort-1 osteotomy for OSA. The patient also received a PPM due to persistent AV block and bradycardia. The patient was discharged in stable condition and will continue to receive regular follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was diagnosed with Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) during this hospitalization. They also had a previous history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and Complete Heart Block (AVB) for which an Artificial Pacemaker (PPM) was implanted. The patient underwent a Lefort Procedure for a fractured jaw, which was successfully completed.   During their hospital stay, the patient experienced a slow heart rate (Brady), and an episode of Atrial Flutter (AFlutter), which was successfully treated with medication. An Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) was also implanted due to the patient's history of Arrhythmias.  The patient will require close follow-up with their cardiologist due to the combination of LBBB and previous AVB, which may increase their risk for future cardiac events. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue their medications and follow-up appointments with their healthcare providers.  It should also be noted that the patient's previous PPM was upgraded to a Biventricular ICD (AICD) due to the combination of RBBB and LBBB.

Patient Name: [redacted]  Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block, completed AV block, Atrial Flutter, and Bradycardia  Medical History: - Born with Lefort I facial fractures, underwent surgeries and healed - Atrioventricular block, treated with pacemaker placement - Junctional rhythm, treated with AICD (Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator) implantation - BiV (Biventricular) pacing, for heart failure management  Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and dizziness. During the hospitalization, the patient underwent an electrophysiology study that confirmed the presence of LBBB and identified a low-grade atrioventricular block. The patient's pacemaker settings were adjusted to BiV pacing mode to optimize cardiac function.  As the patient's atrial flutter persisted despite medical management, the patient underwent electrical cardioversion, which successfully restored sinus rhythm. The patient was then discharged with instructions to continue taking their medications, including warfarin, amiodarone, and metoprolol, and follow up with their cardiologist.  Clinic Follow-Up: The patient followed up with their cardiologist a week after discharge. The patient's ICD (Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) revealed unremarkable findings. The patient's heart rate and rhythm were stable, and the pacemaker was functioning optimally. The patient remained asymptomatic, and no further interventions were necessary.  The patient's medical history of Lefort I fractures requires ongoing dental monitoring and treatment. The patient's clinical course underscores the importance of close cardiovascular follow-up in patients with a history of conduction system defects and ICD implantation.

Patient Name: John Doe  Age: 67 years  Diagnosis: Other left bundle branch block  Medical History:  - Completed junctional rhythm - AV block - AICD (Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) - Lefort procedure - Permanent pacemaker (PPM) implantation - Brady arrhythmia - Biventricular pacing - Atrial flutter  Hospital Course:  Mr. Doe is a 67-year-old male with a past medical history significant for completed junctional rhythm, AV block, AICD implantation, Lefort procedure, permanent pacemaker (PPM) implantation, brady arrhythmia, biventricular pacing, and atrial flutter. He presented to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and fatigue. Admission ECG revealed a new finding of left bundle branch block (LBBB).  During the hospital stay, Mr. Doe was closely monitored via telemetry. He was observed to be in a sinus rhythm with a rate of 70 beats per minute. His electrocardiogram (ECG) showed the presence of LBBB with marked QRS prolongation. The patient had no significant ST-T changes, no evidence of a right bundle branch block (RBBB), or atrioventricular block (AVB).  Subsequently, Mr. Doe underwent an echocardiogram that showed a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction without structural heart disease. He was ultimately discharged on the fourth day after admission with instructions to follow up with his electrophysiologist.  Discharge Summary:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with other left bundle branch block (LBBB) during this hospitalization, which was a new finding on his admission ECG. He was closely monitored during his hospitalization and underwent an echocardiogram, which showed a preserved left ventricular ejection fraction without structural heart disease. He was ultimately discharged after a four-day hospital stay with instructions to follow up with his electrophysiologist. There were no complications or adverse events during his hospital course.

Name: John Doe  Age: 55 years   Sex: Male  Diagnosis: Other left bundle branch block (LBBB)   Medical History:  The patient's medical history is significant for a completed junctional rhythm with an artificial pacemaker (PPM) placement due to a congenital heart block at birth. The patient also has an atrial flutter, which was treated with bifascicular pacing (BIV), and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%.  Hospital course:  John Doe was admitted to the hospital due to intermittent chest pain and shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with an LBBB, which is different from his previous right bundle branch block (RBBB). The patient underwent a LeFort procedure and was successfully managed with medication. He did not develop any AV block or significant bradyarrhythmias requiring intervention. He was discharged home with close follow-up with his cardiologist.  Monitor plan:  The patient was remote-monitored via an intracardiac device (ICD) following his hospital discharge. His ICD showed no significant arrhythmic events or pacing requirement during the follow-up period.  Conclusion:  John Doe has a history of artificial pacing, atrial flutter treated with BIV and low ejection fraction. During his recent hospitalization, he was diagnosed with an LBBB, underwent a LeFort procedure, was managed with medication, and did not develop any significant bradycardia or AV block requiring intervention. He was discharged home and is being closely followed by his cardiologist.

Discharge Summary: Patient with Other Left Bundle Branch Block  This summary is for a patient who has been diagnosed with other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and has undergone various treatments and procedures during their hospital stay.  History: The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease since birth. The patient has undergone several corrective surgeries over the years, including a LeFort procedure. The patient also has complete atrioventricular block (AVB) which required the placement of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) and an automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator (AICD). The patient has a past medical history of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrial flutter (AFL).  Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to worsening heart failure symptoms. During the hospital stay, the patient was monitored closely, and it was noted that the patient had developed other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient underwent several tests, including a stress test and echocardiogram which showed a reduced ejection fraction of 30%. The patient was found to have worsening heart failure and bradycardia, which required hospitalization.  The treatment plan for the patient included optimizing medical therapy for heart failure, which included the addition of biventricular pacing. The patient underwent implantation of a cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) device which was able to manage the patient's heart failure symptoms by pacing both ventricles simultaneously. The patient was also started on anti-arrhythmic therapy for the atrial fibrillation (AF) which included rate control with beta-blockers and anticoagulation.  The patient had a complicated hospital course, including syncope due to junctional rhythm and a requirement for a temporary pacemaker. The patient's condition eventually stabilized after several days, and the patient was discharged home with close follow-up with his cardiologist.  Overall, the patient had a prolonged hospital stay due to the complexity of his medical history, including previous corrective procedures, multiple types of conduction abnormalities, and longstanding heart failure, which required preservation of his cardiac function. With appropriate management and follow-up, the patient's condition can be optimized to improve his quality of life.

Patient Name: John Doe Age: 67 years Sex: Male  Past Medical History: - Brady rhythm - AV block completed junctional - Atrial flutter - Biventricular pacemaker placement - Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) - Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) - AICD (Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator) placement - Lefort 1 fracture reconstruction surgery  Hospital Course: Mr. Doe was admitted to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. Cardiac workup revealed persistent LBBB, an underlying RBBB, and complete junctional AV block. Due to a history of a Brady rhythm, a biventricular pacemaker was previously placed to manage his heart rate. However, given his worsening symptoms, Mr. Doe underwent AICD implantation.  During the hospital stay, Mr. Doe experienced an episode of atrial flutter that was managed with medical intervention. After stabilization, he was discharged home with a plan for close monitoring of his cardiac status and follow-ups with his cardiologist. Further evaluation may be required to re-assess the need for pacemaker programming.  Discharge Diagnosis: - Other Left Bundle Branch Block - RBBB - Complete Junctional AV Block - Bradycardia  Recommendations: 1. Follow-up visit with the cardiologist within 2 weeks of discharge. 2. Continue current medication regimen as prescribed. 3. Wear AICD as instructed and follow-up with device clinics as scheduled. 4. Monitor heart rate and rhythm regularly and report any significant changes to the cardiologist promptly. 5. Lifestyle modifications, such as a heart-healthy diet, exercise, and stress management, should be incorporated to improve overall cardiovascular health.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of abnormal heart rhythms. The patient has a history of congenital heart disease, including a birth defect known as Lefort procedure, permanent pacemaker (PPM) placement, and implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) placement. The implanted devices were placed due to complete heart block, right bundle branch block (RBBB), junctional rhythm, and atrial flutter (AFL).  Upon admission, the patient was found to have Other left bundle branch block (LBBB), which was different from the RBBB found during previous hospitalizations. The patient also had evidence of intermittent bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and atrioventricular block (AVB), which was thought to be related to the LBBB.  After completing various diagnostic tests, including electrocardiogram (ECG) and echocardiogram, the patient was found to have moderate biventricular hypertrophy (enlargement of both ventricles) and a low ejection fraction of 20%. The LBBB was found to be complete, meaning that both branches of the bundle were affected, which can cause delays in the electrical impulses that control the heart's rhythm.  Due to the patient's extensive cardiac history and the severity of the LBBB, the medical team decided to adjust the patient's medications and implant an upgraded ICD system to better monitor and treat the patient's cardiac conditions. Specifically, the ICD system was augmented with a special function known as biventricular pacing, which helps synchronize the heart's pumping actions by pacing both ventricles at the same time.  The patient made a steady recovery and was discharged with ongoing monitoring and management of the LBBB, RBBB, junctional rhythm, AVB, and AFL conditions. The patient was also advised to continue close follow-up with their cardiologist and maintain strict adherence to their prescribed medications and medical devices.

Patient X was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and was found to have a history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), complete atrioventricular block (AVB), and junctional rhythm. The patient had undergone a LeFort procedure in the past and had a pacemaker implanted due to bradycardia.  During the hospital stay, the patient's pacemaker was upgraded to an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) due to a history of atrial flutter and biventricular dysfunction. The ICD was programmed to provide pacing support and defibrillation therapy if needed.  The patient was monitored closely throughout the hospital stay and was discharged in stable condition with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) and ICD. The patient was instructed to follow up regularly with their cardiologist and to closely monitor any symptoms of arrhythmia or heart failure.  In conclusion, Patient X presented with a complex arrhythmic history including LBBB, RBBB, complete AVB, junctional rhythm, aflutter, and biventricular dysfunction. The patient's pacemaker was upgraded to an ICD, and they were discharged in stable condition with appropriate medical management and close follow-up.

Patient X, a [age]-year-old male, presented to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient had a medical history significant for congenital Lefort II facial fractures at birth.  Upon admission, an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which revealed a new diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB), in addition to a previously diagnosed Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB). The patient also had evidence of AV block, as demonstrated by the presence of a completed junctional rhythm.  Given the presence of LBBB and RBBB, the patient was evaluated for cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) and a biventricular implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). Placement of an ICD was recommended after it was found that the patient had a history of atrial flutter (AFL) and bradycardia.  The patient underwent the implantation of a dual-chamber ICD with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) lead in the right ventricular apex. Given the patient's history of AFL and his new diagnosis of Other LBBB, he was also fitted with an atrial ICD (AICD) to manage any potential future arrhythmias.  After the procedure, the patient was closely monitored for any complications. He experienced a brief period of bradyarrhythmia, which was successfully treated with temporary pacing. Post-procedure, the patient's cardiac function improved, and he was discharged with close follow-up instructed.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:  Patient Name: [REDACTED] Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block  Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) at birth, which was treated with a pacemaker implantation (PPM). Later on, the patient also developed Brady-Arrhythmia, and underwent AV Junctional ablation and PPM upgrade to a dual-chamber device with an Atrial Intracardiac Defibrillator (AICD) feature. The patient also had a Le Fort 1 osteotomy for correction of maxillomandibular asymmetry.  Hospitalization History: The patient was admitted to our hospital due to recurrent episodes of atrial flutter and ventricular tachycardia (VT). The patient had a BiV AICD implanted during the hospitalization, which successfully terminated the VT. During the hospital course, a Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) was observed in ECG, which was considered to be completed branch block.  Current Status: The patient was discharged on medications for rate control, anti-arrhythmics, and anticoagulation. The patient was advised to follow-up regularly with the cardiologist and the electrophysiologist. The patient was also referred for genetic testing and counseling for the inherited arrhythmias.  Summary: The patient had a history of LBBB, junctional ablation, PPM implantation, and AICD upgrade, leading to a complex device set-up. The patient was hospitalized for recurrent arrhythmias, leading to BiV AICD implantation. The patient was discharged with a medication regimen and a referral for genetic testing and counseling. RBBB was also observed in ECG during the hospitalization.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other left bundle branch block (LBBB). Initial workup revealed no evidence of any significant underlying cardiac pathology such as right bundle branch block (RBBB), atrioventricular block (AVB) or atrial fibrillation (AFL). The patient underwent a completed junctional ablation procedure following which an artificial intra-cardiac defibrillator (AICD) was implanted to monitor any future rhythm changes.  The patient had a previous history of heart surgery involving the placement of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) and a LeFort procedure for maxillary reconstruction. The patient was admitted with a complaint of brady arrhythmia and intermittent episodes of atrial flutter (AFL).   The patient has been advised to follow up with routine cardiac evaluations at frequent intervals, as the presence of conduction abnormalities such as LBBB and the previous history of procedures involving the heart, can lead to further arrhythmias and other adverse cardiac events. Therefore, the patient has been counselled regarding their management of the AICD and the importance of prompt medical attention should they develop any untoward cardiac symptoms.   In conclusion, the patient was diagnosed with Other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and following further workup, a completed junctional ablation procedure and implantation of an AICD was performed. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with routine follow-up appointments advised.

Patient:   The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The patient presented to the hospital complaining of shortness of breath and fatigue. Further evaluation revealed that the patient had a history of RBBB and AVB, for which he had undergone a completed junctional ablation procedure. Additionally, the patient had received an AICD (automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator) due to the high risk of sudden cardiac death.  Hospitalization:  During the hospital stay, the patient underwent a series of diagnostic tests, including an echocardiogram, which revealed brady and biventricular pacing. The patient's ECG showed LBBB birth branch morphology with anterior septal depolarization, as well as a high-degree AVB with junctional escape rhythm. Furthermore, the patient exhibited symptoms of atrial flutter and required a PPM (permanent pacemaker) for ventricular pacing.  Conclusion:  In conclusion, this patient is diagnosed with Other Left Bundle Branch Block, a rare condition that requires close monitoring and appropriate management of underlying risk factors. The patient's history of RBBB and AVB, as well as the completed junctional ablation procedure and implantable defibrillator, suggest a high risk of sudden cardiac events. The patient's current presentation of brady, biventricular pacing, atrial flutter, and required PPM will require ongoing monitoring and management by a qualified healthcare team.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)  Medical History: Patient had a birth defect, a Lefort 2, which was corrected surgically. Patient also had a completed AV block, for which they received a permanent pacemaker (PPM).   Current Condition: The patient presented with symptoms of fatigue and bradyarrhythmia. The patient's ECG showed a LBBB, with no evidence of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), Atrial Fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, or Atrial Flutter. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation.   Treatment: Due to the patient's history of completed AV block, we initiated the process for an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)/ Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (AICD) placement. During the evaluation process, the patient developed junctional bradycardia, which required urgent intervention. The patient was successfully treated with a biventricular pacing (BiV) pacemaker.   Final Assessment: In conclusion, the patient was diagnosed with Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and had a history of congenital defect (Lefort 2). The patient had a completed AVB and received a permanent pacemaker (PPM). During this admission, the patient developed junctional bradycardia and was treated appropriately with a BiV PPM. The recommended treatment plan consists of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)/ Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (AICD) placement for potential future arrhythmias.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted with a history of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and subsequent diagnosis of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and, Completed Atrioventricular Block (AVB). The patient had undergone a procedure for the installation of an Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (AICD) due to concomitant heart block and Complete AV Block. At the time of admission, the patient had also undergone a surgical procedure for a Lefort 1 Osteotomy.  During the hospital stay, the patient had episodes of Atrial Flutter and Bi-ventricular Dysfunction. The patient was managed with a Temporary Pacing Maker (PPM) and was subsequently implanted with a permanent pacemaker.  The patient was monitored for development of Junctional Rhythm, Bradyarrhythmia, AV Block, and other complications secondary to the temporary pacemaker insertion. The patient did not develop any significant complications, and the temporary pacemaker was removed after 3 days of placement.  The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged with a prescription of Beta-blockers, Antiarrhythmic agents, and diuretics. The patient was advised to follow up with a Cardiologist and continue taking the medications as prescribed.  In summary, the patient was diagnosed with Other LBBB, RBBB, Completed AVB, Atrial Flutter, and required management with an ICD, PPM, and medications. The patient's clinical condition improved during the hospital stay and was discharged with relevant follow-up instructions.

Patient Name: John Doe  Age: 56 years  Gender: Male  Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block   Medical History:  The patient had a history of bradycardia and complete AV block, which was treated with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) insertion. The patient also had a previous LeFort I surgery for facial fractures. The patient had a recent medical history of atrial flutter and completed AV block with a resultant junctional rhythm. The patient had an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) in place for the previous diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB). The patient experienced occasional palpitations and was admitted to the hospital for an evaluation.   Hospital Course:  The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of palpitations. The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed an other left bundle branch block (LBBB) pattern. There was also evidence of a previously noted RBBB pattern on the ECG. The patient had an ICD in place and was found to be pacing in a biventricular mode due to the previous onset of RBBB. The patient reported occasional episodes of the atrial flutter, which was confirmed during the examination.   After monitoring, the patient was treated with medications for rate control. The medications were adjusted to achieve an optimized heart rate. The patient was also advised to continue with daily physical activities, avoid tobacco, and limit alcohol intake. The treating team recommended regular follow-up with their primary care physician to monitor cardiac rhythm and to ensure the effectiveness of the current treatment.   Outcome:  The patient was discharged with instructions to continue medications and follow up with their primary care physician. The ICD programmer was reprogrammed to optimize pacing in view of the recent diagnosis of LBBB. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid triggers that may provoke palpitations. The discharge summary was sent to the primary care physician to ensure continuity of care.   Conclusion:  The patient was diagnosed with other LBBB pattern in the ECGs. The patient had a history of RBBB pattern and had an ICD in place. The patient was found to be pacing in a biventricular mode due to the previous onset of RBBB. The patient was treated with medications for rate control and advised to continue a healthy lifestyle. The patient was also recommended regular follow-up with their primary care physician to monitor cardiac rhythm and to ensure effectiveness of the current treatment plan.

Patient X was admitted with a diagnosed case of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) which was confirmed through electrocardiogram (ECG) tests. The patient underwent a thorough assessment which revealed no other significant cardiac abnormalities apart from a completed LBBB block. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (aflutter) was also diagnosed.  The patient was previously fitted with an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) following a diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB) with junctional escape rhythm. The AICD was functioning without any reported complications.  During the course of the hospitalization, the patient was monitored closely for any signs of bradycardia, and a permanent pacemaker (PPM) was implanted as a preventative measure based on the results of a LeFort stress test. The patient tolerated the procedure well without any associated complications.  Overall, this patient was successfully managed for Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) with a history of previously completed RBBB block, and junctional escape rhythm. The patient was discharged with instructions for continued monitoring of their automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), as well as their newly implanted PPM. Additionally, the patient was instructed to report any new symptoms or concerns to their primary care provider.

Patient John Doe was admitted with a prior diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and was found to have a completed junctional rhythm. Due to a history of atrial flutter (AFL) and bradycardia, he had received an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), also known as an automatic implantable cardiac defibrillator (AICD), which had been previously upgraded from a pacemaker (PPM) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) block indication.   During his hospital course, further evaluation revealed a bifascicular block with a left anterior fascicular block pattern, as well as an asymptomatic atrioventricular block (AVB). Due to the complexity of his arrhythmia, he was scheduled for further outpatient electrophysiology evaluation and potential intervention. Additionally, his history was significant for a LeFort fracture at birth.   The AICD was programmed to deliver therapy for both ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia, given his history of both. He was monitored closely throughout his admission and received appropriate management of his arrhythmias and potential complications. He was ultimately discharged with ongoing cardiology follow-up and a plan for an outpatient electrophysiology study with potential biventricular pacing interventions.

Discharge Summary: The patient was diagnosed with Other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and subsequently underwent a procedure to have an implanted cardiac defibrillator (ICD) with a pacemaker (PPM) inserted. The procedure was completed without any complications. The patient also had a prior history of right bundle branch block (RBBB), atrioventricular block (AVB), and junctional rhythm.  Additionally, the patient had a bi-ventricular pacemaker (BiV PPM) device implanted previously due to chronic bradycardia. The patient also reported a history of atrial flutter (AFL) which was treated with an atrial defibrillator (AICD) successfully.  On review of the patient's medical history, it was discovered that the patient had a history of birth injuries which included facial fractures and maxillary surgery. It was noted that a Lefort procedure was completed in the past. The patient was admitted for observation and subsequently discharged with follow-up appointments scheduled with both the pacemaker clinic and cardiac electrophysiologist.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was diagnosed with Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and completed Junctional rhythm. The patient had a history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and Atrioventricular Block (AVB) that was corrected with a Permanent Pacemaker (PPM) insertion. The patient also had an Atrial Flutter (AFlu) that was corrected with a Bipolar Impedance Vector (BIV) ablation. The patient was admitted for investigation and management of bradycardia and was diagnosed with LBBB block. The patient underwent a successful Lefort procedure and an Implantable Cardiac Defibrillator (ICD) was implanted due to the patient's increased risk of sudden cardiac death. The patient made a good recovery and was discharged with appropriate medications and follow-up plans.

Discharge Summary:  This is a summary of the medical care provided to the patient who was admitted due to Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The patient was initially diagnosed with bundle branch block and subsequently underwent an implantation of an AICD (Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator) due to completed AVB (Atrioventricular Block).  During the patient's hospitalization, they experienced some episodes of bradycardia and aflutter, which were managed appropriately with medications. An echocardiogram was performed, and it showed biventricular function with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 45%. Further diagnostic testing was completed in the form of stress testing using a treadmill, which revealed junctional rhythm and no evidence of myocardial ischemia.  The patient's medical history was significant for a Lefort fracture at birth and a prior implantation of a PPM (Permanent Pacemaker) for RBBB (Right Bundle Branch Block). The patient was informed about the importance of adhering to their medication regimen and continuing routine follow-up with their primary care provider and cardiologist.  The patient was subsequently discharged home in stable condition with appropriate instructions for follow-up care. The patient was advised to continue their medications as prescribed and to monitor their symptoms closely. The patient was also advised to seek medical attention promptly if symptoms worsen or new symptoms develop.

Patient: [Name] DOB: [Date of birth] Diagnosis: Other left bundle branch block  History of presenting illness: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to progressive shortness of breath for the past 3 days. The patient has a history of congenital heart disease and had a LeFort procedure a year ago. The patient also had a permanent pacemaker (PPM) implanted due to complete atrioventricular block (AVB) and recurrent atrial flutter (Aflutter).  Assessment and Treatment: Upon admission, the patient was alert and oriented. Physical examination showed a regular heart rhythm with left bundle branch block (LBBB) and no evidence of right bundle branch block (RBBB). An electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of LBBB and completed AVB (CAVB). The junctional rhythm was noted on telemetry. The implanted cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was interrogated and found to be functioning appropriately.  The patient was treated with intravenous diuretics and antibiotics. The cardiac function was monitored, and the patient was started on biventricular pacing for the LBBB. The patient was eventually stabilized and discharged with a follow-up appointment scheduled with the primary care provider. The patient will be monitored closely with regular ICD checks.  Conclusion: The patient with congenital heart disease presented with progressive shortness of breath and was diagnosed with LBBB with CAVB. The patient had a history of LeFort procedure, PPM implantation, and recurrent Aflutter. Biventricular pacing was initiated to improve the cardiac function, and the patient was discharged in stable condition with close follow-up to monitor the ICD.

Discharge Summary: Patient with Other Left Bundle Branch Block  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The patient was evaluated and diagnosed with a completed junctional rhythm, along with a bradyarrhythmia. The patient had undergone a LeFort I osteotomy and subsequently developed atrial flutter. The patient underwent a successful catheter ablation for atrial flutter and remained in sinus rhythm at discharge.  The patient had a history of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and atrioventricular block (AVB), for which a pacemaker with a pacing mode of dual chamber pacing and rate adaptive pacing was placed. Subsequently, the pacemaker was revised to a permanent pacemaker with a pacing mode of VVI, and was implanted with a biventricular implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) device.  The patient's ICD was checked and found to be functioning normally. The patient was discharged home with instructions for follow-up with the cardiology clinic. The patient was also instructed to monitor for any signs of arrhythmia or pacemaker dysfunction and to contact the clinic for any concerns.  In summary, the patient was diagnosed with Other LBBB and successfully received treatment for atrial flutter. The patient had previously received treatment for RBBB and AVB with the placement of a permanent pacemaker, along with a biventricular ICD device. The patient was advised to follow-up with the cardiology clinic to ensure proper management of their condition.

Patient X was admitted with a diagnosis of other left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient had a medical history including junctional rhythm and complete atrioventricular block (AVB) requiring implantation of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) with an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD). The patient had undergone a previous Lefort I fracture repair during infancy.  During this admission, the patient was found to have right bundle branch block (RBBB) and complete AVB on electrocardiogram (ECG). Atrial flutter with 2:1 AVB was also detected. The patient underwent a biventricular pacemaker implantation with lead placement in the right atrium, right ventricular apex, and left ventricular lateral branch.  Post-operatively, the patient remained in sinus rhythm with biventricular pacing. However, the patient experienced episodes of bradycardia at a rate of 40 beats per minute while in the hospital. The AICD did not detect any ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during this admission.  The patient was discharged with plans to follow up regularly with cardiology for further evaluation of the LBBB and frequent monitoring of the AICD.

Patient is a 68-year-old male with a medical history significant for a left bundle branch block (LBBB) that was detected during a prior visit. During this visit, the patient was found to have a completed junctional rhythm and associated bradyarrhythmia. Additionally, the patient had an atrioventricular block (AVB), which was likely secondary to their LBBB.  Due to the severity of the patient's AVB and potential for further bradyarrhythmias, they underwent placement of an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) with a permanent pacemaker (PPM). The patient was monitored closely after the procedure and demonstrated no complications.  The patient experienced an episode of atrial flutter (AFL) and subsequently received a biventricular (BIV) pacemaker. Following successful placement of the BIV pacemaker, the patient was closely monitored for any further arrhythmias or complications.  Overall, the patient's procedure was successful and they were discharged with appropriate follow-up appointments scheduled. Their LBBB and associated block will continue to be monitored by their healthcare providers, and appropriate interventions will be taken if necessary.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB). The patient has a history of Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB) and Complete Heart Block (AVB), which were both successfully treated with the implantation of a pacemaker, specifically a LeFort Permanent Pacemaker (PPM). During this admission, the patient presented with episodes of atrial flutter (AFL) with rapid ventricular response, which were managed with the administration of medications and the adjustment of the PPM. The patient's rhythm on telemetry remained in a completed junctional rhythm with a heart rate ranging from 50 to 60 bpm. Given the patient's history of previous pacemaker implantation and the ongoing management of the AFL, a decision was made to upgrade the PPM to a Biventricular Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD). The procedure was completed without complications, and the patient was monitored closely in the hospital before being discharged in a stable condition. The patient was advised to follow-up with their cardiologist for further management and monitoring of their cardiac status.

Patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB), a cardiac conduction disorder that affects the electrical signal transmission in the heart. The patient had a history of a completed LeFort procedure and a permanent pacemaker (PPM) implanted due to recurrent episodes of complete atrioventricular block (AVB).  During the hospital stay, an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was inserted due to the presence of atrial flutter (aflutter) with a risk of ventricular tachycardia, which required biventricular pacing. The device was programmed to prevent any rhythmic disturbance using sensing algorithms for brady/tachyarrhythmias.  The patient also experienced episodes of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and heart block, which were treated with junctional pacing by the ICD.  Overall, the patient's condition was managed appropriately with pharmacological and device therapy, and they were discharged in a stable condition with regular follow-ups recommended to monitor the LBBB and its associated risks.

Patient Name: John Doe  Diagnosis: Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) Other Diagnoses: Complete Heart Block, Junctional Rhythm, Atrial Flutter, and Bradyarrhythmia  Medical History:  The patient, John Doe, presented to the hospital with a history of congenital heart disease. He had undergone surgical interventions including a LeFort procedure and the placement of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) due to complete heart block. He also had a history of atrial flutter, which was initially managed with medication but progressed to require the placement of an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD).  Current Hospitalization:  During this hospitalization, John Doe was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath and palpitations. ECG showed Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB) and junctional rhythm. The patient also experienced episodes of bradycardia, requiring adjustments to his AICD settings. Further evaluation revealed Atrial flutter and biventricular dysynchrony due to LBBB. Echocardiogram showed severely reduced left ventricular function.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anti-arrhythmic medication, and his AICD settings were adjusted to prevent further arrhythmias. The cardiology team recommended biventricular pacing (CRT-D) to correct the LBBB. After obtaining informed consent, the patient underwent a successful biventricular implantable defibrillator (ICD) placement, resolving his ventricular dyssynchrony.  Conclusion:  In summary, John Doe was admitted with Other Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB), which was successfully managed with biventricular ICD placement. The patient also had a history of complete heart block, atrial flutter, and bradycardia, which required AICD settings adjustments during the hospitalization. The patient was discharged with follow-up instructions regarding his medications and device management.

Discharge Summary for a Patient with Other Left Bundle Branch Block:  The patient, who had a history of bradyarrhythmia since birth, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of atrial flutter. Upon examination, the patient was found to have other left bundle branch block (LBBB) and an AV block. AICD and ICD were implanted, and the patient underwent successful Lefort surgery to repair the branch block.  Post-surgery, the patient developed a right bundle branch block (RBBB), which was addressed with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) placement. The patient completed the postoperative recovery period without incident and was discharged after the completion of antibiotic treatment.  The patient was advised to continue regular follow-ups with a cardiologist and monitor for any symptoms of arrhythmia. Overall, the procedure was successful, and the patient expressed relief from the previously experienced symptoms.
